Mr. Eden was the guest at lunch in Ahwaz on 7th January of Mizbah Fat end, the Governor-General of Khuzistan. 2. Mr. Eden thought that you might like to know that in the subsequent private conversation the Governor- General stated that this province was now quiet and contented. The Governor-General was convinced that, by cooperating with the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company he was acting in the best interests of the Persian Government. The programme of improvements in housing and welfare envisaged by the Anglo-Irani an Oil Company would, he felt, result in the present happy conditions being maintained. Also, with the assistance of the Company, Ahwaz might well become one of the best towns in Persia in a very short time. 3. Mr. Eden replied that Great Britain wished to see Persia remain a free and independent sovereign state. There were certain realities in foreign affairs today and one of them was that Persia and Great Britain must work together. Satisfactory labour conditions and a contented people constituted the best means of resisting Communism. 4. Afterwards Mr. Eden told me that he had been impressed by the Governor-General who had a remarkable record of co-operation with British interests during [groups omitted ]. 5. Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 23, these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence regarding the visit of Anthony Eden and his son to the Middle East. Related matters of discussion include the following: approval of the visit from the Secretary of State for Commonwealth Relations; arrangements for the visit, including details of all the places where the Edens will be staying.The file also contains political opinion regarding Persia, and a schedule of the twenty-three-day visit to the Middle East.The file features the following principal correspondents: the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf; the Commonwealth Relations Office, the Foreign Office, officers acting on behalf of the British Middle East Office, Cairo.The file includes a divider which gives the subject number, the year the subject file was opened, the subject heading, and a list of correspondence references by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.
